question: [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Function: default()] [Insecure Default] Does the default proc_cores of 4 provide sufficient parallel verification, or can it be exploited to cause verification bottlenecks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Function: default()] [Insecure Default] Is the default random_seed of 1 secure, or does it make verification deterministic in a way that attackers can exploit to predict verification behavior? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Function: default()] [Insecure Default] Does the default stratification_depth of 6 provide sufficient function expansion depth, or can shallow depth miss verification conditions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Function: default()] [Insecure Default] Are the default eager_threshold and lazy_threshold of 100 appropriate for security-critical verification, or can they allow incomplete quantifier instantiation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Function: default()] [Insecure Default] Does defaulting serialize_bound to 0 (unlimited) create risk of memory exhaustion during large serialization operations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Function: default()] [Insecure Default] Is defaulting keep_artifacts to false secure, or does it hide verification issues that should be auditable through artifact inspection? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Function: default()] [Insecure Default] Does defaulting hard_timeout_secs to 0 (no timeout) allow verification processes to run indefinitely, creating DoS risk? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Function: get_version()] [Version Spoofing] Can an attacker create a fake tool executable that returns a valid version string matching the regex but implements malicious verification logic? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Constant: MAX_BOOGIE_VERSION] [Outdated Version Risk] Does enforcing MAX_BOOGIE_VERSION='3.5.1.0' prevent using newer Boogie versions with critical security fixes, creating a security gap? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Constant: MIN_Z3_VERSION] [Version Pinning] Does requiring exactly Z3 version 4.11.2 (MIN=MAX='4.11.2') create risk if vulnerabilities are found in that specific Z3 version? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Function: check_version_le()] [Version Comparison Bug] Can version comparison fail when comparing versions with different precision (e.g., '3.0.1' vs '3.0.1.0'), allowing incompatible versions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Constant: MIN_CVC5_VERSION] [Unbounded Upper Version] Does having MAX_CVC5_VERSION=None allow using untested future CVC5 versions with potential incompatibilities or vulnerabilities? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Function: get_mod_analysis_flag()] [Flag Confusion] Can an attacker exploit the version-dependent switch between -doModSetAnalysis and -inferModifies to cause inconsistent modifies clause verification? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Constant: MOD_SET_ANALYSIS_LEGACY_FLAG] [Deprecated Feature] Does using the legacy -doModSetAnalysis flag with older Boogie versions create verification gaps in modifies clause checking? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Constant: MOD_SET_ANALYSIS_NEW_FLAG_SINCE_3_5_1] [Version Boundary] Can edge cases at exactly version 3.5.1.0 cause ambiguity about which modifies analysis flag to use? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Struct: CustomNativeOptions] [Template Injection] Can an attacker inject malicious Boogie code through template_bytes that gets executed during custom native function generation? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Function: custom_native_options()] [Module Trust] Are the hardcoded modules '0x1::object' and '0x1::aggregator_v2' properly sandboxed, or can compromised core modules exploit custom native generation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Struct: CustomNativeOptions] [Instance Key Injection] Can an attacker manipulate module_instance_names keys to cause collisions or override legitimate native function implementations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Struct: CustomNativeOptions] [Type Confusion] Can the single_type_expected boolean flag be exploited to create type confusion in generic native function instantiation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Struct: BorrowAggregate] [Name Collision] Can an attacker create multiple BorrowAggregate entries with the same name field causing verification logic conflicts? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Struct: BorrowAggregate] [Aggregate Mismatch] Can mismatched read_aggregate and write_aggregate names cause incorrect mutable borrow semantics verification? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Function: BorrowAggregate::new()] [Validation Missing] Does the constructor validate that name, read_aggregate, and write_aggregate are non-empty and properly formatted? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Field: borrow_aggregates] [Vector Manipulation] Can an attacker add duplicate or conflicting BorrowAggregate entries to cause verification soundness issues? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Field: loop_unroll] [Insufficient Unrolling] Can setting loop_unroll to a small value (e.g., 1) cause verification to miss bugs that only manifest after multiple loop iterations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-prover/boogie-backend/src/options.rs] [Field: loop_unroll] [Over Unrolling] Can setting loop_unroll to None disable loop unrolling entirely, causing loops to be treated abstractly and missing concrete loop bugs? (High)
